results.title: First citizen: Albert Namatjira
results.creator_credit: John Tristram, I. James Wilson and Juniper Films
results.brief_description: First Citizen charts the life of aboriginal painter, Albert Namatjira. Born in 1902, Albert Namatjira rose to star status through the acceptance of his art by white Australia in the 1950s. As a result, he was awarded Australian citizenship in 1958. What followed was an often tragic life, caught between white Australian and Aboriginal cultures.
results.creator_credit_for_label: John Tristram, I. James Wilson and Juniper Films

results.title: First break
results.creator_credit: Derek Rogers, Adrienne Amato, Silva Basmajian and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: The ongoing struggle of living with a diagnosed mental illness is portrayed in this program through candid interviews over one year with three teenagers, who are experiencing mental illness, and their families. Their personal stories, shared with great sensitivity and honesty, illuminate the challenges and dis-orientating effects of mental illness as well as its impact on their conception of their self-identities and their relationships with family and friends. As the camera follows the course of their lives over this period we are given an insight into their own hopes, strengths and achievements as well as their frustrations in dealing with their mental illness in every day life. “First Break” also questions the stigmatised view of mental illness through these very personal stories, providing a portrait of young people coping with their experiences and the powerful changes it has meant for their own as well as their families lives.

results.title: First born = Premier-ne
results.creator_credit: Joan Henson, Colin Low, Susan Huycke and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: A film of poetic intent, set in Canada’s Pacific Rim National Park, where a woman giving birth, dreams of the growing infant. From the beauty of the images and the evocative music and sound effects, the viewers are impelled toward their own interpretation. Sound film without words.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Joan Henson, Colin Low, Susan Huycke and National Film Board of Canada

results.title: Firelight = Clair-Obscure
results.creator_credit: Paul Bochner, Wolf Koenig and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: A highly personal and impressionistic piece of work, Firelight explores time. This animated film has long dissolves and pastel shades which reflect its ephemeral nature, its steady progression and the constancy of its cycles. It is a gentle film that sets the mind adrift. Film without words. Music by Eldon Rathburn.

results.title: Fire Woman and Tristan's Ascension: Bill Viola opening night
results.brief_description:
On October 6th 2010, Father Michael Elligate of St Carthage’s Catholic Church in Parkville introduced John Kaldor and Bill Viola, formally launching the exhibition. Presented by ACMI along with Melbourne International Arts Festival and Kaldor Public Art Projects, the exhibition gave Melbourne audiences a unique chance to experience the work of one of the world’s more influential and important artists.

John Kaldor speaks of his admiration for Bill Viola’s work, and his contemporary use of the moving image, Bill in turn talks about his work, processes and inspirations.

Bill Viola has been instrumental in the establishment of video as a vital form of contemporary art. For over 40 years he has created videotapes, architectural video installations, sound environments, electronic music performances, flat panel video pieces and works for television broadcast. His video installations - total environments that envelop the viewer in image and sound - employ state-of-the-art technologies and are distinguished by their precision and direct simplicity.

results.title: Fire Woman and Tristan's Ascension: Bill Viola installation and interviews
results.brief_description:
This film captures the installation of the large projection screen and associated audio visual equipment needed to showcase Bill Viola’s works, ‘Fire Woman’ & ‘Tristan’s Ascension’. The exhibition took place at St Carthage’s Catholic Church in Parkville and the film features a short introduction by John Kaldor and interviews with Bill Viola and Father Michael Elligate.

Bill Viola has been instrumental in the establishment of video as a vital form of contemporary art. For over 40 years he has created videotapes, architectural video installations, sound environments, electronic music performances, flat panel video pieces and works for television broadcast. His video installations, total environments that envelop the viewer in image and sound, employ state-of-the-art technologies and are distinguished by their precision and direct simplicity.

results.title: Living with disaster: stories and experiences from disasters
results.brief_description: ‘Living with disaster’ is a major project by ACMI in collaboration with the Attorney General’s Department through its Emergency Management division and the CFA, in order to capture stories of young people who have survived natural disasters.

results.title: When the flood comes
results.brief_description: The Newcastle floods of 2007 have caused Djibril Ly to reflect on growing up in Mauritania in West Africa. He recalls the devestation of flooding and how this has helped him to prepare for similar events in Australia.

results.title: When a fire comes to you
results.brief_description: When the threat of fire hit Lydia Romari’s family, they adopted their fire plan and stayed safe. Unfortunately, it doesn’t erase the frustration, anxiety and horror of the Black Saturday bushfires that devestated much of the Yarra Ranges region in Victoria in 2009.

results.title: Ready and able
results.brief_description: Members of the CFA provide practical advice on how to prepare for and survive a major catastrophe like a bushfire or a flood. These interviews were conducted in light of the tragic Black Saturday bushfires in February 2009.
